notes:
1. Definition

Uniform Circular Motion describes the motion of a particle traveling in a circular path at a constant speed. Although the speed is constant, the velocity vector is continuously changing direction, which means the particle is accelerating.

2. Kinematics

  • Angular Velocity ($\omega$): The rate of rotation is constant. $\omega = \frac{d\theta}{dt}$.
  • Angular Acceleration ($\alpha$): Since $\omega$ is constant, $\alpha = \frac{d\omega}{dt} = 0$.
  • Tangential Velocity ($v_t$): The linear speed of the particle tangent to the path. $v_t = r\omega$.
  • Tangential Acceleration ($a_t$): The rate of change of speed. Since speed is constant, $a_t = \frac{dv_t}{dt} = r\alpha = 0$.

3. Normal (Centripetal) Acceleration

Even though tangential acceleration is zero, there is always an acceleration directed toward the center of the circle, responsible for changing the direction of the velocity.

$$ a_n = \frac{v_t^2}{r} = r\omega^2 $$

This is called the normal or centripetal acceleration.

solvedExamples.question: For a particle in uniform circular motion, which of the following statements is true?
solvedExamples.explanation: In uniform circular motion, the magnitude of the velocity (speed) is constant. However, the velocity vector changes direction, so velocity is not constant. This change in direction requires a non-zero normal acceleration.

solvedExamples.question: A car travels around a circular track of radius 50 m at a constant speed of 20 m/s. What is the magnitude of its acceleration?
solvedExamples.explanation: Since the speed is constant, the tangential acceleration is zero. The only acceleration is the normal (centripetal) acceleration. $a_n = v^2 / r = (20 \text{ m/s})^2 / 50 \text{ m} = 400 / 50 = 8 \text{ m/s²}$.
